title: Fanny Durack
text:
Sarah Frances "Fanny" Durack (27 October 1889 – 20 March 1956), also known by her married name Fanny Gately, was an Australian competition <a href="swimming%20%28sport%29">swimmer</a>. From 1910 until 1918 she was the world's greatest female swimmer across all distances from <a href="freestyle%20swimming">freestyle</a> sprints to the mile marathon.
Life and career.
Durack learned to swim in Sydney's <a href="Coogee%20Baths">Coogee Baths</a> using <a href="breaststroke">breaststroke</a>, the only style for which there was a championship for women at that time. In 1906 she won her first title, and over the next few years, dominated the Australian swimming scene. In the 1910-11 swimming season, <a href="Mina%20Wylie">Mina Wylie</a> beat Durack in the 100-yard breaststroke and the 100- and 220-yard freestyle at the <a href="Australian%20Swimming%20Championships">Australian Swimming Championships</a> at Rose Bay. The two went on to become close friends.
From late 1912 to 1920, Durack held the official women's Freestyle swimming world record for 100 metres. She also held the 200M freestyle record from 1915 to 1921. Other world records held included 220 yards freestyle (1915 to 1921), 500M freestyle (1916 to 1917) and 1 mile freestyle (1914 to 1926). She also held many Australian and State records.
The New South Wales Ladies Swimming Association initially was opposed to women participating in the Olympic Games. The <a href="1912%20Summer%20Olympics">1912 Summer Olympics</a> in Stockholm was to be the first Olympics to have women's swimming. Durack and Wylie were initially refused permission by NSWLSA to compete, but later they were allowed to go provided they bore their own expenses. They organised local fundraising to raise the funds for themselves as well as for the obligatory chaperones. Durack set a new world record in the heats of the 100-metre freestyle. She won the final, becoming the first Australian woman to win an Olympic gold medal in a swimming event. Until the <a href="1932%20Summer%20Olympics">1932 Olympics</a> (when <a href="Clare%20Dennis">Clare Dennis</a> won the 200-metre breaststroke in Los Angeles) she was the only such woman; and until the <a href="1956%20Summer%20Olympics">1956 Olympics</a> she and Dennis were the only two such women.
A week before the Australian team left for the 1920 <a href="1920%20Summer%20Olympics">Antwerp Olympics</a>, in May 1920, Durack suffered appendicitis and had an emergency appendectomy. This was followed by typhoid fever and pneumonia and she was unable to participate in the Olympic team.
During <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a>, the statue of Mary and the infant Jesus on top of the Basilica of Notre-Dame de Brebières in <a href="Albert%2C%20Somme">Albert, Somme</a>, France, was hit by a shell on 15 January 1915, and slumped to a near-horizontal position. Australian troops nicknamed the leaning statue "Fanny", in honour of Fanny Durack as it resembled the swimmer diving off the blocks.
Death and legacy.
Durack died in Sydney in 1956. She was interred in <a href="Waverley%20Cemetery">Waverley Cemetery</a>, together with her late husband Bernard Martin Gately. Fanny Durack Aquatic Centre in <a href="Petersham%2C%20New%20South%20Wales">Petersham</a>, Sydney, is named in her honour.
She was posthumously inducted into the <a href="International%20Swimming%20Hall%20of%20Fame">International Swimming Hall of Fame</a> as an "Honour Swimmer" in 1967. In addition to this, she was inducted onto the <a href="Victorian%20Honour%20Roll%20of%20Women">Victorian Honour Roll of Women</a> in 2001.
Sarah Durack Ave at <a href="Sydney%20Olympic%20Park">Sydney Olympic Park</a> in <a href="Sydney">Sydney</a>, Australia is named in honour of her.
